questions.text: Shoulder dystocia can result in all of the following except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

All the options listed are documented complications of shoulder dystocia, involving both maternal and fetal outcomes. Hence, none of the above is the correct answer.

questions.text: All are done in the management of shoulder dystocia except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Fundal pressure is contraindicated in shoulder dystocia as it can worsen fetal impaction by forcing the anterior shoulder further against the maternal symphysis.

In contrast, the other manoeuvres listed are part of the standard management protocol for shoulder dystocia.

Shoulder Dystocia:

The term shoulder dystocia is used to define a wide range of difficulties encountered in the delivery of the shoulders (A head-to-body delivery time exceeding 60 seconds defines shoulder dystocia)

Turtle sign positive: Head delivers but retracts against the symphysis pubis.

First-line measures :

  • Immediately after recognition, call for help- an obstetrician, a paediatric resuscitation team and an anaesthetist.
  • McRoberts' manoeuvre (Option B) is the single most effective intervention and should be the first manoeuvre to be performed. The McRoberts manoeuvre is flexion and abduction of the maternal hips, positioning the maternal thighs on her abdomen.
  • Moderate suprapubic pressure (Option C) can be applied by the assistant.
  • Maternal pushing should be discouraged, as this may lead to further impaction of the shoulder, thereby exacerbating the situation.
  • Avoid fundal pressure

Second-line measures: They should be done only if first-line measures fail

  • Internal rotation manoeuvre- Wood's manoeuvre (Option D): It is a progressive rotation of the posterior shoulder by 180°. So that the impacted anterior shoulder is released.
  • Delivery of the posterior arm

Third-line measures- They should be done only if the second-line measures fail:

  • Cleidotomy: Fracturing the clavicle bone of the fetus
  • Symphysiotomy: Dividing the pubic symphysis of the mother
  • Zavanelli manoeuvre: Replacing the head of the baby back into the pelvis, followed by cesarean section.

choices.text: Lateral cutaneous nerve of the thigh

questions.text: Sudden hyperflexion of the thighs over the maternal abdomen (McRoberts manoeuvre) may result in injury to which of the following nerves?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

McRoberts manoeuvre is the first-line intervention in shoulder dystocia. It involves hyperflexion and abduction of the maternal hips, aligning the femurs with the maternal spine.

  • This straightens the sacrum relative to the lumbar vertebrae, rotates the symphysis pubis towards the maternal head, and reduces the angle of pelvic inclination.
  • It effectively widens the pelvic outlet and facilitates shoulder delivery.
  • However, excessive force or duration may cause stretch injury to the lateral cutaneous nerve of the thigh, leading to numbness or paresthesia over the anterolateral thigh (meralgia paresthetica).

Explanation of Other Options:

Common peroneal nerve (Option A): Courses laterally near the fibular head; more commonly injured due to prolonged squatting or lithotomy position, not the McRoberts manoeuvre.

Obturator nerve (Option B): Lies deep within the pelvis; typically affected in pelvic surgeries or prolonged fetal head compression against the lateral pelvic wall, not by thigh hyperflexion.

Lumbosacral trunk (Option C): Deeply located and rarely affected by positioning manoeuvres; may be involved in pelvic fractures or high-impact trauma.

choices.text: Abduct the mother's thigh and apply suprapubic pressure
Flex mother's thighs onto her abdomen
Push the infant's head back into the uterus and perform a cesarean section

questions.text: A 28-year-old primigravida at 39 weeks' gestation delivers the head of the baby, but the head then retracts against the perineum, and the shoulder delivery does not progress despite gentle traction. What is the first step in the management of this condition?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

McRoberts manoeuvre is the first-line management step in shoulder dystocia and should be initiated immediately when the turtle sign is noted.

  • Shoulder dystocia is suspected when the head delivers and retracts ("turtle sign") and the shoulders fail to follow.
  • McRoberts manoeuvre involves:
    • Hyperflexing and abducting the mother's thighs onto her abdomen.
    • Straightening the lumbosacral angle and rotating the symphysis pubis anteriorly.
    • Increasing pelvic outlet space to facilitate delivery.
  • Most effective and first manoeuvre; resolves up to 40-90% of cases alone.
  • Fundal pressure is contraindicated as it worsens impaction and risks fetal injury.
  • If McRoberts fails:
    • Suprapubic pressure is applied next.
    • Rubin/Woods manoeuvre and delivery of the posterior arm are second-line.
    • Zavanelli manoeuvre or cleidotomy are last-resort interventions.

Explanation of Other Options:

Abduct the mother's thigh and apply suprapubic pressure (Option A): This is part of the second step, after McRoberts. Suprapubic pressure helps dislodge the anterior shoulder but is not the first intervention.

Apply fundal pressure (Option B): Contraindicated in shoulder dystocia, it increases fetal impaction and risk of uterine rupture or fetal injury.

Push the infant's head back and perform a cesarean section (Option D): This is the Zavanelli manoeuvre, a third-line, last-resort measure if all others fail. Not done first.

choices.text: Occurs in cases of obstructed labour
Usually involves the fundal area first
Margins of rupture are ragged and necrosed
FHS is absent in all cases

questions.text: Which of the following statements is not true regarding obstructive uterine rupture?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

In obstructive uterine rupture, the most commonly involved site is the anterior lower uterine segment, not the fundus. Rupture is associated with prolonged obstructed labour and leads to ragged, necrosed margins of the torn myometrium due to ischemia and infection.

choices.text: Application of fundal pressure and immediate delivery of the baby

questions.text: Mrs. Reshma, a 20-year-old primigravida, was brought from a village with labour pains for the past 28 hours. She laboured at home under an untrained dai for 24 hours, was later referred from a PHC with the diagnosis of a big baby not deliverable vaginally. On arrival, she appears exhausted and dehydrated. Uterine contractions are absent, and fetal heart sounds are not audible. What is the best management step for this patient?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The clinical presentation strongly suggests a ruptured uterus following prolonged obstructed labour, a life-threatening obstetric emergency requiring immediate surgical intervention.

Key diagnostic features:

  • History of prolonged obstructed labour
  • Absence of uterine contractions
  • Absence of fetal heart sounds
  • Clinical signs: maternal exhaustion, dehydration, possible shock
  • Abdominal findings: superficial fetal parts, loss of uterine contour
  • Vaginal findings: recession of the presenting part, bleeding

Management:

  • Immediate resuscitation (fluids, antibiotics, oxygen)
  • Emergency laparotomy is the definitive treatment to control haemorrhage, remove the fetus, and repair or excise the uterus if needed

Explanation of Other Options:

Immediate instrumental delivery (Option A): Contraindicated in suspected uterine rupture, especially when the fetus is already dead and the uterus is ruptured; it increases the risk of maternal morbidity and further trauma.

Application of fundal pressure and immediate delivery of baby (Option B): Dangerous in obstructed labour or uterine rupture-can exacerbate uterine tear, haemorrhage, and maternal mortality.

Start oxytocin for uterine contraction (Option D): Absolutely contraindicated in suspected uterine rupture; may worsen haemorrhage and jeopardise maternal life.

questions.text: A 30-year-old G3P2 woman with a history of previous lower segment cesarean section presents to the labour room at 39 weeks of gestation with complaints of the sudden onset of severe abdominal pain, followed by cessation of uterine contractions and fetal bradycardia on cardiotocography. On examination, she is pale, hypotensive, with a distended abdomen and absent fetal heart sounds. Per vaginal exam reveals no presenting part felt and minimal bleeding. What is the most likely cause of maternal death in this scenario?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

This clinical scenario describes a ruptured uterus, most commonly occurring in women with a history of cesarean section (TOLAC) or obstructed labour.

  • The primary causes of maternal death in a ruptured uterus are:
    • Haemorrhage leading to hypovolemia (Option A)
    • Shock (hypovolemic and sometimes neurogenic) (Option B)
    • Sepsis, especially in delayed or mismanaged cases (Option C)
  • Late sequelae include:
    • Adhesions → intestinal obstruction
    • Scar rupture in subsequent pregnancies

questions.text: A 30-year-old female presents with signs of obstructed labour. She is febrile, dehydrated, and examination reveals intrauterine fetal demise (IUFD) with cephalic presentation. What is the best next step in management?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

In modern obstetric practice, cesarean section (LSCS) is the most appropriate and safe intervention even in cases of obstructed labour with IUFD, particularly when the head is high and moulding is severe.

  • Obstructed labour is a life-threatening condition for the mother, and immediate action is needed to:
    • Correct dehydration and electrolyte imbalance
    • Start broad-spectrum antibiotics
    • Relieve the obstruction surgically, most often via cesarean section
  • Although destructive procedures (e.g., craniotomy, decapitation) were used in the past, they are now obsolete in well-equipped settings due to:
    • Risk of maternal trauma
    • Prolonged time and difficulty
    • Availability of safer alternatives (LSCS)

Explanation of Other Options:

Craniotomy (Option A): A Destructive procedure previously used in cases of IUFD with cephalic presentation, but is obsolete in modern obstetrics.

Decapitation (Option B): Used in cases of shoulder presentation or transverse lie with IUFD, not applicable here.

Forceps extraction (Option D): Contraindicated in obstructed labour when the head is high; may cause trauma or uterine rupture.

choices.text: There is no place for a wait-and-watch policy
Dehydration and ketoacidosis should be promptly corrected
Oxytocin has a definite place in the management

questions.text: The following statements are related to the management of obstructed labour except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Oxytocin is contraindicated in obstructed labour. In obstructed labour, the uterus is already contracting adequately against a mechanical obstruction. Administering oxytocin increases the risk of uterine rupture.

Core management principles of obstructed labour include:

  • Immediate resuscitation:
    • IV fluids to correct dehydration and ketoacidosis
    • IV broad-spectrum antibiotics to prevent sepsis
  • Definitive management:
    • Prompt surgical intervention (typically cesarean section)
    • In select cases with IUFD and an engaged head, destructive operations may be considered
  • Avoid:
    • Oxytocin worsens the obstruction and increases the risk of rupture
    • Expectant management (wait and watch) is not appropriate

Explanation of Other Options:

There is no place for a wait-and-watch policy (Option A): Correct; delays increase maternal and fetal morbidity.

Dehydration and ketoacidosis should be promptly corrected (Option B): Correct; part of the initial resuscitation.

choices.text: The ring is always felt on abdominal examination
Usually situated around the neck of the fetus in cephalic presentation
There is no progress of labour
The ring is felt during caesarean section or manual removal of the placenta

questions.text: Regarding the constriction ring, all of the following are correct except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The Constriction ring (Schroeder’s ring) is a localised area of myometrial contraction forming a circular muscular band of the uterus. It occurs most often at the junction of the upper and lower uterine segments and typically forms around the fetal neck in cephalic presentations, especially during instrumental deliveries or excessive oxytocin use.

  • Not felt abdominally: It is typically diagnosed intraoperatively (e.g. during cesarean or forceps delivery), not palpated reliably on abdominal exam.
  • Common locations: Around the fetal neck, especially in cephalic presentation.
  • Effect: Causes obstructed labour due to a lack of descent or delivery.
  • Identification: Felt as a tight ring compressing the fetus during C-section or during manual removal of the placenta.

Constriction ring:

Retraction ring:



Explanation of Other Options:

Usually situated around the neck of the fetus (Option B): Correct; commonly seen in cephalic presentations.

There is no progress of labour (Option C): Correct; it causes dystocia by preventing fetal descent.

The ring is felt during caesarean or manual removal (Option D): Correct; it is an intraoperative finding.

questions.text: A 22-year-old primigravida at term is brought to the emergency room after being in labour for over 24 hours under the supervision of an untrained birth attendant. On examination, she is dehydrated and tachycardic (pulse 100/min), BP is 120/80 mm Hg. Abdomen reveals a fundal height of 36 weeks, cephalic presentation, fetal heart sounds are absent, and mild uterine activity is noted. Vaginal exam shows a fully dilated cervix, station +1, with caput, moulding, and dirty, foul-smelling discharge. The pelvis appears clinically adequate. What is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The patient presents with classical signs of obstructed labour in a primigravida with intrauterine fetal demise (IUFD), dehydration, and prolonged labour with infection.

  • Cesarean section remains the safest option in such patients to prevent maternal morbidity and complications such as uterine rupture or sepsis.
  • Use of oxytocin in obstructed labour is contraindicated due to the risk of uterine rupture from an already thinned-out lower uterine segment. (Option B)
  • Craniotomy and destructive procedures are obsolete and no longer recommended in modern obstetrics, especially in primigravida with infection. (Option D)
  • Although the cervix is fully dilated and the station is +1, vacuum-assisted delivery is contraindicated due to the presence of infection and cephalopelvic disproportion (CPD) signs (caput, moulding). (Option C)
